item.title: Episode #1
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

item.title: Episode #2
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

item.title: Episode #3
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

item.title: Episode #4
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
I'm Josephine Sanchez

In 2014, I began publishing personal essays exploring my journey through divorce, mental illness, and an undiagnosed learning disability. That experience showed me style without life is just imitation.

3.3 million followers later, Artemiz has become a resource for others to feel less alone in the ups and downs of their journey through life. It's a place where readers can find suggestions on where to travel, eat, or shop from someone they’ve come to know as a friend.

Thank you for being here. For being open to enjoying life’s simple pleasures and looking inward to understand yourself, your neighbors, and your fellow humans! I’m looking forward to chatting with you.

item.title: Blog Single
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
If 2020 has taught me anything—and God help us all if it hasn’t imprinted a laundry list of lessons onto our nervous systems—it’s a sense of impermanence.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times. Josephine Sanchez Blogger, Designer & Art Director

My home isn’t my home, but somebody else’s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn’t know where. Five years later I’m still here, which I didn’t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you’re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.

Which is why I’m not sure why I’ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can’t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven’t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I’ve regretted in life are the things I didn’t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.

Josephine Sanchez

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) 

That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.

“Home is more than housing,” Sass says. “It’s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and/or allows you to grow.”

Exactly. Here are Sass’s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.

Consider Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.

“If you are familiar with Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,” Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. “You might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.”

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.

This picture has been taken in 2020

Ask yourself these key questions.

“How do I…”

“How do I want to…”

“What fosters my ability to…”

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let’s look at sleep. Here’s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:

Light: “I’d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don’t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.”

Sound: “Textiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces—rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.”

Bedding: “Bedding is one area where I’d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.”

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car.

“You’ll want to take them with you, and you’ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,” Sass says. She recommends if you’re not in your forever home to invest in:

  • Chairs > sofas
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls
  • Lamps > light fixtures

There you have it. I’m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I’m not there yet, but I’m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can’t see that far yet.

Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.

fa-quote-left","library":"fa-solid"},"primary_color":"#F1A953","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false},"_position":"absolute","_offset_x":{"size":-153,"unit":"px"},"_offset_y":{"size":-19,"unit":"px"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"icon"},{"id":"1d9e43cf","elType":"section","settings":{"border_radius":{"unit":"px","top":"5","right":"5","bottom":"5","left":"5","isLinked":true}},"elements":[{"id":"468b7bc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"background_background":"classic","background_color":"#ECECEC","border_radius":{"unit":"px","top":"5","right":"5","bottom":"5","left":"5","isLinked":true},"margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"72","right":"50","bottom":"76","left":"50","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"36d3ad0f","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.<\/p>","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Lora","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":24,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_font_style":"italic","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"10","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"3eac5738","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Josephine Sanchez","header_size":"h3","align":"center","title_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false},{"id":"341b9676","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":58.6,"space_between_widgets":0,"margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"100","bottom":"0","left":"45","isLinked":false},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"3cdd4628","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Even if you\u2019re not living in your forever house, and don\u2019t know when or where you\u2019ll be moving next, don\u2019t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don\u2019t you think? (I think.) <\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"35","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"24dad64a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

That said, now likely isn\u2019t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don\u2019t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It\u2019s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"35","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"289a03d3","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"1ebe6b30","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":820,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"77a7bcc3","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"41e5821a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cHome is more than housing,\u201d Sass says. \u201cIt\u2019s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and\/or allows you to grow.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"2d91a7e2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Exactly. Here are Sass\u2019s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"50","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"35960348","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Consider Maslow\u2019s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"439b2138","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cIf you are familiar with Maslow\u2019s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,\u201d Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. \u201cYou might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"498ba7f2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"35b00421","elType":"section","settings":{"layout":"full_width","margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":0,"bottom":"80","left":0,"isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"60e440ef","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"space_between_widgets":0,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"3585ec3c","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/frenify.com\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/Layer-17.jpg","id":142},"image_size":"full","width":{"unit":"%","size":100,"sizes":[]},"space":{"unit":"%","size":100,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"7501cd73","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"This picture has been taken in 2020","align":"center","title_color":"#BBBBBB","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":14,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_font_style":"italic","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":60,"sizes":[]},"_background_background":"classic","_background_color":"#000000CC","_position":"absolute","_offset_orientation_v":"end"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5ddd229b","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":820,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"57f0db51","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"584aa915","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Ask yourself these key questions.","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"76e87396","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cHow do I\u2026\u201d<\/p>\n

\u201cHow do I want to\u2026\u201d<\/p>\n

\u201cWhat fosters my ability to\u2026\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"17a96043","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let\u2019s look at sleep. Here\u2019s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"6d3b5fb4","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Light:<\/strong> \u201cI\u2019d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don\u2019t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"9b2f045","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Sound:<\/strong> \u201cTextiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces\u2014rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"178cbff6","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Bedding:<\/strong> \u201cBedding is one area where I\u2019d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"68f3d207","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":1420,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"b48b070","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"2ced23c8","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/frenify.com\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/Untitled-65.jpg","id":135},"image_size":"full"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"23d513e8","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Photos by Frenify Team Studio","header_size":"span","align":"center","title_color":"#888888","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":14,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_font_style":"italic","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"16ffbfef","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":820,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"54cc4e86","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"dcdc72e","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car. ","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"5700b394","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cYou\u2019ll want to take them with you, and you\u2019ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,\u201d Sass says. She recommends if you\u2019re not in your forever home to invest in:<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"4b866c70","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    \n
  • Chairs > sofas<\/li>\n
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls<\/li>\n
  • Lamps > light fixtures<\/li>\n<\/ul>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"27babc11","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    There you have it. I\u2019m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I\u2019m not there yet, but I\u2019m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can\u2019t see that far yet.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"7021818a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: Podcast Single
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: https://frenify.net/envato/frenify/wp/artemiz.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: The Organization Method That Improved My Everyday Routines
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
If 2020 has taught me anything—and God help us all if it hasn’t imprinted a laundry list of lessons onto our nervous systems—it’s a sense of impermanence.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times. Josephine Sanchez Blogger, Designer & Art Director

My home isn’t my home, but somebody else’s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn’t know where. Five years later I’m still here, which I didn’t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you’re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.

Which is why I’m not sure why I’ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can’t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven’t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I’ve regretted in life are the things I didn’t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.

Josephine Sanchez

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) 

That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.

“Home is more than housing,” Sass says. “It’s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and/or allows you to grow.”

Exactly. Here are Sass’s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.

Consider Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.

“If you are familiar with Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,” Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. “You might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.”

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.

This picture has been taken in 2020

Ask yourself these key questions.

“How do I…”

“How do I want to…”

“What fosters my ability to…”

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let’s look at sleep. Here’s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:

Light: “I’d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don’t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.”

Sound: “Textiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces—rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.”

Bedding: “Bedding is one area where I’d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.”

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car.

“You’ll want to take them with you, and you’ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,” Sass says. She recommends if you’re not in your forever home to invest in:

  • Chairs > sofas
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls
  • Lamps > light fixtures

There you have it. I’m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I’m not there yet, but I’m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can’t see that far yet.

Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.

item.title: 4 Styling Strategies to Make Your Home a More Joyful Place
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
If 2020 has taught me anything—and God help us all if it hasn’t imprinted a laundry list of lessons onto our nervous systems—it’s a sense of impermanence.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times. Josephine Sanchez Blogger, Designer & Art Director

My home isn’t my home, but somebody else’s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn’t know where. Five years later I’m still here, which I didn’t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you’re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.

Which is why I’m not sure why I’ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can’t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven’t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I’ve regretted in life are the things I didn’t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.

Josephine Sanchez

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) 

That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.

“Home is more than housing,” Sass says. “It’s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and/or allows you to grow.”

Exactly. Here are Sass’s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.

Consider Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.

“If you are familiar with Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,” Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. “You might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.”

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.

This picture has been taken in 2020

Ask yourself these key questions.

“How do I…”

“How do I want to…”

“What fosters my ability to…”

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let’s look at sleep. Here’s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:

Light: “I’d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don’t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.”

Sound: “Textiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces—rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.”

Bedding: “Bedding is one area where I’d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.”

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car.

“You’ll want to take them with you, and you’ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,” Sass says. She recommends if you’re not in your forever home to invest in:

  • Chairs > sofas
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls
  • Lamps > light fixtures

There you have it. I’m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I’m not there yet, but I’m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can’t see that far yet.

Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.

item.title: 5 Convincing Ways to Apply for a Job Even When You’re Not Qualified
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
If 2020 has taught me anything—and God help us all if it hasn’t imprinted a laundry list of lessons onto our nervous systems—it’s a sense of impermanence.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times. Josephine Sanchez Blogger, Designer & Art Director

My home isn’t my home, but somebody else’s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn’t know where. Five years later I’m still here, which I didn’t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you’re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.

Which is why I’m not sure why I’ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can’t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven’t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I’ve regretted in life are the things I didn’t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.

Josephine Sanchez

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) 

That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.

“Home is more than housing,” Sass says. “It’s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and/or allows you to grow.”

Exactly. Here are Sass’s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.

Consider Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.

“If you are familiar with Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,” Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. “You might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.”

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.

This picture has been taken in 2020

Ask yourself these key questions.

“How do I…”

“How do I want to…”

“What fosters my ability to…”

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let’s look at sleep. Here’s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:

Light: “I’d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don’t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.”

Sound: “Textiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces—rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.”

Bedding: “Bedding is one area where I’d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.”

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car.

“You’ll want to take them with you, and you’ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,” Sass says. She recommends if you’re not in your forever home to invest in:

  • Chairs > sofas
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls
  • Lamps > light fixtures

There you have it. I’m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I’m not there yet, but I’m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can’t see that far yet.

Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.

So, perhaps like many of you, I\u2019ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I\u2019ve been riding out these uncertain times.","testimonial_image":{"url":"https:\/\/frenify.com\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/girl.jpg","id":113},"testimonial_image_size":"thumbnail","testimonial_name":"Josephine Sanchez","testimonial_job":"Blogger, Designer & Art Director","testimonial_alignment":"left","content_typography_typography":"custom","content_typography_font_family":"Lora","content_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"content_typography_font_weight":"400","content_typography_font_style":"oblique","image_size":{"unit":"px","size":70,"sizes":[]},"name_text_color":"#444444","name_typography_typography":"custom","name_typography_font_family":"Heebo","name_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"name_typography_font_weight":"500","job_text_color":"#888888","job_typography_typography":"custom","job_typography_font_family":"Heebo","job_typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":14,"sizes":[]},"job_typography_font_weight":"400"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"testimonial"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true},{"id":"1f4d380c","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

My home isn\u2019t my home, but somebody else\u2019s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn\u2019t know where. Five years later I\u2019m still here, which I didn\u2019t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you\u2019re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"75c9a70c","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Which is why I\u2019m not sure why I\u2019ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can\u2019t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven\u2019t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I\u2019ve regretted in life are the things I didn\u2019t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"71","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"41cfc33","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":1420,"sizes":[]},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"7b078e73","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"space_between_widgets":0,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"7ff94561","elType":"widget","settings":{"gallery":[{"id":49,"url":"https:\/\/frenify.net\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/08\/unnamed-file.jpg"},{"id":106,"url":"https:\/\/frenify.net\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/8-2.jpg"},{"id":108,"url":"https:\/\/frenify.net\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/7-2.jpg"}],"border_radius":{"unit":"px","size":5,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"frel-gallery"},{"id":"78600806","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Photos Even if you\u2019re not living in your forever house, and don\u2019t know when or where you\u2019ll be moving next, don\u2019t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don\u2019t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn\u2019t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don\u2019t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It\u2019s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"dee63c7","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":1000,"sizes":[]},"content_position":"top","structure":"20","margin":{"unit":"px","top":"40","right":0,"bottom":"0","left":0,"isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"a757bc","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":41.4,"content_position":"top","space_between_widgets":20,"background_color":"#ECECEC","border_radius":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":true},"margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":true}},"elements":[{"id":"2520af8e","elType":"widget","settings":{"selected_icon":{"value":"fas Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.<\/p>","align":"center","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Lora","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":24,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_font_style":"italic","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"10","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"bf994af","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Josephine Sanchez","header_size":"h3","align":"center","title_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":true}],"isInner":false},{"id":"7438eca","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":58.6,"space_between_widgets":0,"margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"100","bottom":"0","left":"45","isLinked":false},"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"4730dc8a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

It\u2019s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"35","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"8ffa7ec","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"174dbb3","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":820,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"37790f11","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"2e647f44","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cHome is more than housing,\u201d Sass says. \u201cIt\u2019s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and\/or allows you to grow.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"6e04f957","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Exactly. Here are Sass\u2019s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"50","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"6d4bd60","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Consider Maslow\u2019s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"32178182","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cIf you are familiar with Maslow\u2019s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,\u201d Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. \u201cYou might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"63707d62","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"27cfe9a5","elType":"section","settings":{"layout":"full_width","margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":0,"bottom":"80","left":0,"isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"788cb344","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"space_between_widgets":0,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"74ccc4a5","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"http:\/\/artemiz.frenify.com\/1\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/Layer-17.jpg","id":144},"image_size":"full","width":{"unit":"%","size":100,"sizes":[]},"space":{"unit":"%","size":100,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"0","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"513903c7","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"This picture has been taken in yourself these key questions.","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"420814ee","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cHow do I\u2026\u201d<\/p>\n

\u201cHow do I want to\u2026\u201d<\/p>\n

\u201cWhat fosters my ability to\u2026\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"36f748fd","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let\u2019s look at sleep. Here\u2019s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"7fff7a17","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Light:<\/strong> \u201cI\u2019d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don\u2019t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"389fcb6f","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Sound:<\/strong> \u201cTextiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces\u2014rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"cec8f57","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Bedding:<\/strong> \u201cBedding is one area where I\u2019d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.\u201d<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b0993c","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":1420,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"128d9394","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"462ae9ac","elType":"widget","settings":{"image":{"url":"https:\/\/frenify.com\/envato\/frenify\/wp\/artemiz\/wp-content\/uploads\/2020\/09\/Untitled-65.jpg","id":135},"image_size":"full"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"image"},{"id":"2e64ca60","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Photos by Frenify Team Studio","header_size":"span","align":"center","title_color":"#888888","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":14,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_font_style":"italic","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"70","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"48c35dbd","elType":"section","settings":{"content_width":{"unit":"px","size":820,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[{"id":"4461f754","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null,"padding":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"10","bottom":"0","left":"10","isLinked":false}},"elements":[{"id":"2701e1df","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car. ","header_size":"h3","title_color":"#000000","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":30,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"500","_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"18","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"171293c9","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

\u201cYou\u2019ll want to take them with you, and you\u2019ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,\u201d Sass says. She recommends if you\u2019re not in your forever home to invest in:<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"3bed6869","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    \n
  • Chairs > sofas<\/li>\n
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls<\/li>\n
  • Lamps > light fixtures<\/li>\n<\/ul>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"313adcda","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    There you have it. I\u2019m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I\u2019m not there yet, but I\u2019m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can\u2019t see that far yet.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]},"_margin":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"15","left":"0","isLinked":false}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"29c845a2","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

    Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.<\/p>","text_color":"#444444","typography_typography":"custom","typography_font_family":"Heebo","typography_font_size":{"unit":"px","size":18,"sizes":[]},"typography_font_weight":"400","typography_line_height":{"unit":"px","size":28,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
I'm Josephine Sanchez

In 2014, I began publishing personal essays exploring my journey through divorce, mental illness, and an undiagnosed learning disability. That experience showed me style without life is just imitation.

3.3 million followers later, Artemiz has become a resource for others to feel less alone in the ups and downs of their journey through life. It's a place where readers can find suggestions on where to travel, eat, or shop from someone they’ve come to know as a friend.

Thank you for being here. For being open to enjoying life’s simple pleasures and looking inward to understand yourself, your neighbors, and your fellow humans! I’m looking forward to chatting with you.

item.title: Our Favorite Drugstore Beauty Products That Won’t Break the Bank
item.dc:creator: frenify
item.content:encoded:
If 2020 has taught me anything—and God help us all if it hasn’t imprinted a laundry list of lessons onto our nervous systems—it’s a sense of impermanence.

Entire industries can implode. Two of them I worked in did. So can relationships. In mine, on a Tuesday we were planning details for a road trip to Montana—car ride snacks, an isolated wood cabin in the Crazy Mountains, days to do nothing but be together—and by Friday my future of promises and plans with my partner was gone. Most importantly though, the concept of life itself is proving itself, now more than ever, fragile. It’s easy, too easy, how quickly everything can be taken away. This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times.

This awareness of impermanence has me desperate for something, anything I can cling to for comfort. So, perhaps like many of you, I’ve sought out refuge at home, my safe haven where I’ve been riding out these uncertain times. Josephine Sanchez Blogger, Designer & Art Director

My home isn’t my home, but somebody else’s home. When I moved in, I intended to stay for four months, a pit stop on my way to I didn’t know where. Five years later I’m still here, which I didn’t expect but am grateful for, entrusting that the universe will kick me out when the time is right. I thought I would have It All figured out by now, but it turns out while you’re waiting for life to happen, life is happening.

Which is why I’m not sure why I’ve lazily propped framed art on shelves instead of putting a nail in a wall. I truly can’t stand this rug, every day resenting it more, but I haven’t changed it. It took me five years of procrastinating and five minutes on eBay to finally buy a lamp to replace one I inherited and hate. The only things I’ve regretted in life are the things I didn’t do sooner, including making my (not-so) temporary space the best home I can make it.

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

The Benefits of Experimenting

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Home is where love resides, memories are created, friends always belong, and laughter never ends.

Josephine Sanchez

Even if you’re not living in your forever house, and don’t know when or where you’ll be moving next, don’t you deserve the comfort of home, wherever that home is? Life is too short to live with that lumpy mattress, don’t you think? (I think.) 

That said, now likely isn’t the time to throw down thousands of dollars on decor. The good news is, you don’t have to. Small changes in your home can make big changes in your life. It’s not the things, but the feelings, which hopefully are brought out by the things.

Here to help is Victoria Sass, founder and principal designer of Minneapolis-based Prospect Refuge Studio.

“Home is more than housing,” Sass says. “It’s an extension of yourself, a place where you can truly be yourself. Home is also a state of mind. It could be a social place or a place of refuge; it might be a space that holds memories and/or allows you to grow.”

Exactly. Here are Sass’s top tips for making a temporary space feel like home.

Consider Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs in your design.

“If you are familiar with Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs, think about the base two levels of your needs,” Sass says. Maslow breaks it down to the basics: air, water, food, shelter, security, and health. “You might be surprised how few spaces actually, truly, meet those needs. Think about how you eat, how you rest, what makes you feel healthy and safe.”

Take eating, for example. That could mean dedicating a space for dining, not the indent in the couch in front of your TV, or even simply reorganizing your refrigerator. Maybe you invest in kitchen tools that encourage you to cook or replace the harsh overhead light with a softer bulb. Think small and simple.

This picture has been taken in 2020

Ask yourself these key questions.

“How do I…”

“How do I want to…”

“What fosters my ability to…”

Finish the question with your most important needs: sleep, work, eat. Make small, practical changes in your space to better facilitate those needs. Let’s look at sleep. Here’s how Sass tackles three of the most important design aspects for quality sleep:

Light: “I’d recommend investing in curtains that give you the privacy you desire and block light (or don’t) depending on your needs. Dimmable lamps are always a good idea. Think symmetry in your bedroom for balanced vibes.”

Sound: “Textiles in your sleeping space will muffle sound and envelope you in a cozy, womblike way. Think about all your surfaces—rugs, wall textiles, an upholstered headboard, curtains, or soft seating.”

Bedding: “Bedding is one area where I’d invest, invest, invest. Find your perfect fiber and buy the best you can afford. A complete bedding set will feel the most inviting at the end of a long day.”

Photos by Frenify Team Studio

Invest in moveable objects that are smaller than your car.

“You’ll want to take them with you, and you’ll want it to not be a pain in the ass to do it,” Sass says. She recommends if you’re not in your forever home to invest in:

  • Chairs > sofas
  • Small foldable kilim rugs > heavy wool beastly rolls
  • Lamps > light fixtures

There you have it. I’m considering everything about this year a lesson in embracing temporary. I’m not there yet, but I’m starting at home. Allow yourself to look ahead, even if we can’t see that far yet.

Take that, 2020. And you too, 2021.
